description: From Middle English flicche, from Old English fliċċe (“side of an animal, flitch”), from Proto-Germanic *flikkiją (“side, flitch”), from Proto-Indo-European *pleh₁ḱ- (“to tear, peel off”). Cognate with Low German flikke, French flèche, Icelandic flikki (“flitch”), Middle Low German vlicke.

entries.meaning: The flank or side of an animal, now almost exclusively a pig when cured and salted; a side of bacon.
examples: The following morning before Nicholas awoke, Mulvey walked all the way to the village of Letterfrack, returning with a basket of cabbages and a flitch of bacon, two loaves of fresh bread and a plump broiling chicken.

entries.meaning: A piece or strip cut off of something else, generally a piece of wood (timber).
examples: The Measure of a shell or Flitch of Timber.
If a piece be taken out of the middle of a round piece of Timber from end to end; there will be left two pieces, which they call Shells or Flitches.

verbs.description: flitch (third-person singular simple present flitches, present participle flitching, simple past and past participle flitched)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut into, or off in, flitches or strips.
